Proposed measures include: (i) a £2 stake limit on online slot machines; (ii) an end to betting by credit card; (iii) restrictions on “VIP” accounts; (iv) an investigation into non-disclosure agreements. The article states that the group believe that ‘they have a good chance of influencing gambling policy, regardless of the outcome of the general election…while the prime minster is thought to be sympathetic to calls for stricter regulation’. The report singles out the Gambling Commission as ‘not fit for purpose in the age of internet gambling and required greater powers to sanction companies’. The Gambling Commission has responded that ‘the report does not reflect our considerable action and progress on most of the areas of concern set out in the report and we look forward to being given the chance to outline that work to the APPG'. The report highlights the continued risk to operators from further UK regulation.

Irish HF guy @WEB, that is how the €400 disappeared, €1 and €2 bets. You can even put the Keno machine on automatic betting.
Irish HF guy IGT machines of course.
BE11:20am

[W]e explored the downside risk to GVC and WMH from various hypothetical UK regulation scenarios such as (i) a higher PoC tax (from 15% to 25%) and RGD (from 21% to 25%), or (ii) a TV advertising ban assuming no cost savings and 2% lower revenue growth. We estimated an EPS hit in 2020E to GVC/WMH of 15%/35% from the combination of the two scenarios above. While it is hard to quantify the impact of the measures set out by the APPG, we estimate that c.25-30% of GVC’s group revenues is from online casino vs. c.20-25% of group revenues for WMH in 2020E (predominantly UK-driven for both). GVC (OW, PT 1050p) is our preferred gaming pick, and we view today’s announcement of Barry Gibson as chairman as positive given his experience in the gambling and retail sector.

BE11:31am

Last week the RICS published its Q3 2019 UK Commercial Property Market Survey which suggests a deterioration in sentiment (62% of survey participants are of the opinion that the propert market is in the early to middle stages of a downturn) in part due to ongoing Brexit uncertainty being detrimental to market activity. Savills City and West End Market Watch reports highlight a stable market even if we see a shock exit from serviced office providers. It notes that WeWork has accounted for 20% of space let this year in the West End and 26% in the City. Less than a third (28%) of WeWork’s Central London commitments are in the West End making it more insulated than the City. However, even if it did walk away from all its commitments, Savills estimates it would equate to 15 months’ worth of supply in the West End and 18.5 months’ in the City up from around 12 months at present (but importantly both below the 20 months oversupply trigger point). Our expectation of consolidation in the serviced office market is starting to play out with Property Week reporting that IWG is in talks to buy Central Working out of administration after acquiring The Clubhouse out of administration a few weeks ago. Turning to the retail property market, we highlight an article in The Sunday Times which states that landlords are running out of patience with retailers playing the CVA card. It details the situation at Regis UK (owner of Supercuts) which collapsed into administration last month after going through a CVA last year (challenged by landlords due to the belief the business had been asset stripped by its US parent). The expectation is that with more CVAs being challenged there may be fewer CVAs going forward but unfortunately with trading so poor, there is unlikely to be a slowdown in the number of administrations (remembering that more than half of retailers that undergo a CVA subsequently collapse - Mothercare reportedly today putting administrators on standby in relation to its UK business being a case in point).

Forester @ #REF Most bookies do not allow deposits from Skrill or Neteller. I am sure you can guess why!

arget price 240p | Publication price 202p

We turn BUY for the first time in three years. Management’s decisive actions are delivering results, giving us much more belief that FY20E earnings will be a trough. H1 reporting (26th Nov) should reassure that the momentum is continuing and the recent share price dip provides a good opportunity to buy ahead of this news. The shares have run strongly overall YTD, but we see upside as the market gains more confidence that earnings and FCF will positively inflect.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Now competitive in Food

Our pricing survey shows PETS own-brands are now up to c.20% cheaper than third-party equivalents. On key third-party brands PETS’ is now within c.5% of online rivals vs. being up to 25% more expensive in 2017. Price investment has left Retail gross margin at a more sustainable level.

Growing subscription base

Existing Puppy Club members alone offer a c.£130m p.a. revenue pool (13% of FY20E sales). Flea / worm medication could offer a £70m+ p.a. sales opportunity. Alongside vet healthcare plans, these are driving more recurring, higher margin revenue streams and better visibility.

FCF step-up from FY21E

Releasing cash from the Vet Group should create significant value. We forecast FCF of over £70m+ p.a. from FY21E, after exceptionals in FY20E fall away. Our total FY20E-23E FCF is greater than 20% of the current market cap.

240p TP (+20%upside)

Our TP, implying a CY20E PER of 16.5x, is derived from the average of our DFC and ROIC/WACC analyses. It is very close to the float price of 245p in March 2014. We think the business is better positioned now.

Cash generation began on a declining trend under previous management. We think a turning point is approaching as the Vet Group reset lays the platform for sustainable profit growth and improving cash generation. There will be material outflows (up to c.£27m) in FY20E, largely relating to the restructuring, including vet buy-backs and closures. However, these should fall away and allow a step-up to £70m+ of FCF p.a. from FY21E onwards. The balance sheet will de-lever from an already healthy position, meaning additional cash returns could factor.

Anyway, Caz forecasts coming back towards reality.

BE11:56am

Fevertree remains a quality growth story with long term potential
(either organically or to be acquired). However in the short term,
sentiment and the share price is dominated by 4-week Nielsen data,
which at best is incomplete and has been unhelpful recently. We think
the long term opportunities in continental Europe and the US as
outlined in our initiation (here) are still relevant, though our
expectations for the UK are reduced as market share gains stall nearterm.
Fevertree is trading on 30x 2020E P/E (4-year absolute and
relative lows) for 10% EPS CAGR on our forecasts (with upside
potential in all markets). A 40% de-rating since May provides an
interesting entry point for a long-term growth story, despite the near
term noise – we stay Overweight.

BE11:56am

Mixed messages from Nielsen. According to Nielsen, in its
measured channels/markets Fevertree’s European sales declined
1.2% in Q3 (with the UK -3.9%), while the US picked up to c37%
growth. For a product that over-indexes to the on-trade, Nielsen can
be a useful indicator; however at best, we believe it can account for
c40% of group sales, in which sales are volatile (not least in the
difference in sell-in and sell-out trends). While gin category growth
has slowed in Europe, premiumisation remains a long-term driver.
The last few months have been disappointing in Europe, though we
note that these months are relatively small (with the
December/Christmas period accounting for c20-25% of annual sales
as consumers up-trade to more premium mixers) and in most
markets, Fevertree's distribution penetration continues to grow which
is positive for long term market share gains.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Reduced forecasts though still upside potential. As we take a more
cautious view on the UK (now low-single digit organic sales growth
vs mid-to-high single digit previously) as well as FX headwinds, we
bring our forecasts down 4-6%. On the basis of our reduced
estimates, our DCF-derived December-2020 valuation comes down
to £24.00. On our forecasts, Fevertree trades on 30x 2020E P/E for
10% mid-term EPS CAGR. While the near-term downgrades are
disappointing, the long term Fevertree expansion story is intact with
potential for upgrades in the US (base case c30% CAGR) and Europe
(c20% CAGR). In the absence of an official update from the
company, in the near term shares are likely to be volatile as strong
US Nielsen data readings are offset by weaker numbers in Europe.

Irish HF guy Interestingly, Thomas Henry (*1734) was an English apothecary and chemist. In addition to his medical work he also invented the conservation of drinking water by adding sodium carbonate. Amongst others, this invention was of great benefit for the British Navy, as from now on seamen could be supplied with fresh water on long seafarings (and not only with rum..). Thereby Thomas Henry was one of the first producers of soda water - next to the German Johan Jacob Schweppe, who patented his method in 1783 and distributed his products as well in London in 1792 under the name "Schweppes". But it remains unclear to us, why the manufacturers of Thomas Henry Tonic Water have used the portrait of Thomas´ son, William Henry, for the label and not Thomas Henrys´...

Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 4,165, up 41 (+0.99%), High: 4,177, Low: 4,131, Volume: 70.87k
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

[W]e initiate coverage on Whitbread with a Buy recommendation and 4,800p target price. We believe the current share price is missing the value locked up in: (i) the growth strategy; and (ii) the freehold assets. Room capacity at Premier Inn will increase 22% based on the committed pipeline and could more than double. Valuation is underpinned by £5bn of freeholds. Management will steadily recycle/return capital as appropriate. A bidder could plan to release capital more quickly. We forecast 69% EPS growth FY20-24E driven by 23% capacity growth to 101k rooms (from 77k today). Our 4,800p target price is based on the long-term growth and asset realisation potential discussed in our note. With the hotel cycle turning there is a risk that negative forecast momentum caps the short-term share price upside.
